You use Junit in the same way for integration tests as for unit tests . The
only difference is that while writing Unit tests you will have to write
pseudo Classes, that a method you are testing, refers to, while in
Integration testing you replace these pseudo classes by the actual classes.
In unit testing you control the input that will come from the interacting
classes while in integration testing the values are actually
computed/fetched by the objects/classes.

There are two cases:

First, when you have been writing unit tests for each class in JUnit from
the start. In this case the "Test suite" that includes test classes will
serve the purpose you are looking for in integration testing framework.

Second, you have not written any tests for your classes till now and now you
need to change a class that interacts with other classes. In this case I
will suggest you to write test cases for this class and test it thoroughly.
Next you will need to trace the interaction of this class (maybe from the
design document) with other classes and write test to ensure that the
requirements are met.

If the system design is OO and the design document is well done, all you
will need to understand are the responsibilities of this class of objects
and modify accordingly.

Regards,

Sachin
